channel.title: Prototype Quest System (vid)
channel.description:
[rant]There's so many private RSC-servers out there, they've lost their flavour. Nothing is unique anymore and creativity is lost. It's all 'reach 99 99 99 in a week' pk servers for lazy people whose excuse for persuading developers into making the game excruciatingly easy is 'they have a life', and so they can't train under more difficult conditions. And so when the training factor is removed, their 'busy lives' become 24/7 pking with their easy stats. Next people will be asking for inbuilt autocatchers because they're too busy to pk properly. The sense of 'work for your rewards' is gone, which was the key element in RSC, the game everyone here used to love. Whatever.[/rant]
Quests - the only unachieved gem in RSC server development, the only feature that truly implements diversity into a RSC server drowned in a sea of useless junk.
[url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=biO3jeq5Q0s]http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=biO3jeq5Q0s[/url]
There's an example of my working prototype Quest system, fully scriptable and functional with database storing. It's about 60% done, and it didn't take long at all. It's time to mix this boring shit up a bit and create some real variety in this bland environment. I post this here as proof that things outside of the box are possible, and as an encouragement to fellow RSC server developers to quit copying eachother and do something [b]different[/b]. Quests are possible, they're not difficult to code if you know what you're doing, so where the hell are they?
Come on guys, do something new. We won't learn anything by copying eachother's poor-quality StorkPK rip-offs. Make your own games!
Good day.
Love, punKrockeR.

item.title: Prototype Quest System (vid)
item.dc:creator: @Rancid2 Rancid`.
item.description:
@Rancid2 wrote:

[quote=“Stork, post:11, topic:188351”]I’m impressed. Finally, some real progress on an rsc server.
So how did you do it? Mediator had some ideas with waypoints and such (can’t remember exactly how he wanted it done). If it’s scriptable and flexible, that’s good work.[/quote]

Thanks man. If I remember right, Mediator said something about having an int[] array in Player.java that stored the quest’s ‘stage’. If that’s correct, that’d mean the quests were probably also intended to be hard-coded into the server. Obviously I’m not going to post the source code to my quest system (at least not just yet) because last time all that seemed to encourage was lazy plagiarism, not acceleration of RSC server development like I was hoping. But I’ll explain it so that people who actually know how to code have some idea of how my system works - I’m sure there’s a billion alternative possible systems that would work just as well.

It’s probably not the most efficient method, but it’s the only method I could think of that truly allowed complete scriptability and control over quests. Basically, when the server starts, it loads the quest class files out of a folder called ‘quests’ (much like old RSC bots loading from the ‘scripts’ folder). A playable quest extends Quest.class (Methods.class with STS as a comparison - Quest holds all the quest-specific commands and the link to the Player owner and the server engine) It loads the .class files into memory (not the Quest objects due to the inability to correctly instantiate abstract classes that have been loaded directly, resulting in all quests having the same owner lol), and then when a player logs in, their QuestManager creates all the Quest objects with the player as the owner. Kind of hard to explain easily, but it works.

I’ll let the source code to the example TestScript explain the rest as much as possible.

[code]
import com.rscd.quest.;
import com.rscd.model.;
import com.rscd.event.*;

/**

  • A basic test of the quest system’s capabilities.

  • @author punKrockeR
    /
    public class TestQuest extends Quest
    {
    /    *

    • This is the quest’s UniqueID. IT MUST BE UNIQUE, as it’s the
    • database identifier. Conflicting quest UIDs will result
    • in many angry people, do not mess this up.
      */
      public final static int UID = 1;

    /**

    • The TestQuest constructor, all quests need one,
    • it defines the basics of the quest (its owner and UID).
      */
      public TestQuest(Player owner, Integer uid)
      {
      super(owner, UID);
      }

    /**

    • This is an abstract Method, and as such
    • must be overwritten by every subclass of
    • Quest. It defines the unique features of
    • each quest - its name, its ‘completion stage’,
    • any items, npcs, objects that are associated
    • with it.
      */
      public void define()
      {
      setName(“Sheep shearer”); // Sets the name of this quest.
      setFinalStage(100); // The stage at which this quest ends.
      associateNpc(77); // Fred the farmer
      associateNpc(3); // Chicken
      associateItem(10); // Coins
      associateObject(0); // Tree
      }

    /**

    • Also an abstract Method that must be overwritten.

    • This is called when the getFinalStage() is met.
      */
      public void completeQuest()
      {
      getOwner().getInventory().add(new InvItem(10, 500)); // Give the player 500 coins
      getOwner().getActionSender().sendInventory();

      getOwner().getActionSender().sendMessage(((Npc)getOwner().getTalking()).getDef().getName() + " hands you 500 coins.");
      getOwner().incExp(12, 500); // 500 Crafting xp

      sleep(2500);

      getOwner().getActionSender().sendMessage(“You have completed " + getName() + “!”);
      getOwner().getActionSender().sendMessage(”@gre@You just gained 1 quest point!"); // Yet to code client-side, so display a dummy for now.
      }

    /**

    • This is my own method I made for organization’s sake,

    • and has nothing to do with the Quest superclass.

    • It handles all the main quest line’s stage progression.
      */
      private void handleNpc(final Npc npc)
      {
      if(npc.getID() == 77) // Fred the Farmer
      {
      if(!questStarted()) // Say start quest dialogue.
      {
      sayNpcMessage(“Hi there, traveller. Care to make some money?”);
      sleep(1500);

       	new QuestMenu(getOwner(), new String[] { "Sure, what do I need to do?", "No thanks, I'm good." }) // Creates a new option menu.
 	{
 		public void handleReply(final int option)
 		{
 			if(option == 0)
 			{
 				sayMessage("Sure, what do I need to do?");
 				sleep(1200);
 				sayNpcMessage("If you collect 10 balls of wool for me, I'll pay you 500 coins.");
 				sleep(3000);
 				sayNpcMessage("Maybe I'll teach you a thing or two about crafting, too.");
 				sleep(3000);
 				sayNpcMessage("I'm afraid you'll have to find your own shears, but the sheep are outside.");
 				sleep(3000);

 				new QuestMenu(getOwner(), new String[] { "Sorry, I don't like the sound of that.", "I'd be happy to help." })
 				{
 					public void handleReply(final int option)
 					{
 						if(option == 0)
 						{
 							sayMessage("Sorry, I don't like the sound of that.");
 							sleep(1200);
 							sayNpcMessage("Suit yourself. Good day, then.");
 							sleep(1000);
 						} else
 						{
 							setStage(1); // The user has begun the quest - set its stage to 1.
 							
 							sayMessage("I'd be happy to help.");
 							sleep(1200);
 							sayNpcMessage("Great! Come back and see me when you're done.");
 							sleep(1000);
 						}
 					}
 				};
 			} else // The player declined the quest.
 			{
 				sayMessage("No thanks, I'm good.");
 				sleep(1200);
 				sayNpcMessage("Suit yourself. Come and see me if you change your mind.");
 				sleep(1000);
 				
 			}
 			
 			stopTalking(); // Reset talking vars and MobState.
 			getOwner().setMenuHandler(null); // Remove this menu handler.
 		}
 	};
 } else
 if(getStage() == 1) // We've already started this quest.
 {
 	sayNpcMessage("Ahh, you've returned! Do you have my wool?");
 	sleep(1200);
 	
 	new QuestMenu(getOwner(), new String[] { "Yes, I do.", "I'm afraid not." })
 	{
 		public void handleReply(final int option)
 		{
 			if(option == 0)
 			{
 				sayMessage("Yes, I do.");
 				sleep(1200);
 				if(owner.getInventory().countId(207) < 10) // Check if we actually have the balls of wool.
 				{
 					sayNpcMessage("Um, no you don't. Get back to me when you do. The reward still stands!");
 					stopTalking();
 					getOwner().setMenuHandler(null);
 				} else
 				{
 					sayNpcMessage("Execelent! Hand them over, then.");
 					sleep(1200);
 					
 					owner.getActionSender().sendMessage("You hand over 10 balls of wool to " + npc.getDef().getName() + ".");
 					sleep(1200);
 					
 					for(int i = 0; i < 10; i++) // Remove the wool.
 						owner.getInventory().remove(owner.getInventory().getFirstIndexById(207));
 						
 					owner.getActionSender().sendInventory();	
 						
 					sleep(1200);
 					sayNpcMessage("Thank you very much! As promised, here's your reward.");
 					sleep(1200);
 					setStage(getFinalStage()); // Complete the quest.
 						
 					stopTalking();	
 					getOwner().setMenuHandler(null);		
 				}
 			} else
 			{
 				sayMessage("I'm afraid not.");
 				sleep(1200);
 				sayNpcMessage("Well, come and see me when you do. The offer still stands");
 				stopTalking();
 				getOwner().setMenuHandler(null);
 			}
 		}
 	};
 } else
 {
 	if(completed()) // We've already finished this NPC's quest, so just say a polite hello.
 		sayNpcMessage("Hey there, " + getOwner().getUsername() + ". Thank you for your help with the wool!");
 		
 	stopTalking();
 }

      }
      }

    /**

    • This is an optional trigger. If an entity that has been associated

    • (associateNpc(), associateItem(), associateObject() etc.) has been

    • interacted with in any way by the player, this will be called, along

    • with the QuestTrigger enum to define the action.
      */
      public void triggerEntity(QuestTrigger trigger, Entity entity)
      {
      if(entity instanceof Npc) // This entity is an NPC.
      {
      Npc npc = (Npc)entity;

       if(trigger == QuestTrigger.NPC_KILLED) // We killed the NPC.
 {
 	if(npc.getID() == 3) // chicken
 	{
 		getOwner().getActionSender().sendMessage(getName() + " You killed a chicken.");
 		setStage(1);
 	}
 } else
 if(trigger == QuestTrigger.NPC_TALK) // We're talking to the NPC (For Fred the farmer, not the chicken).
 {
 	handleNpc(npc);
 }

      } else
      if(entity instanceof InvItem) // This entity is an InvItem.
      {
      InvItem item = (InvItem)entity;

       if(trigger == QuestTrigger.ITEM_PICKUP) // We picked the item up.
 {
 	getOwner().getActionSender().sendMessage(getName() + " - You picked up a " + item.getDef().getName());
 } else
 if(trigger == QuestTrigger.ITEM_DROP) // We dropped the item.
 {
 	getOwner().getActionSender().sendMessage(getName() + " - You dropped a " + item.getDef().getName());
 }

      } else
      if(entity instanceof GameObject) // This entity is a GameObject.
      {
      GameObject object = (GameObject)entity;

       if(trigger == QuestTrigger.OBJECT_ACT1) // We acted upon command 1 of this object
 {
 	getOwner().getActionSender().sendMessage(getName() + " - You acted on " + object.getDef().getName());
 } else
 if(trigger == QuestTrigger.OBJECT_ACT2) // We acted upon command 2 of this object
 {
 	getOwner().getActionSender().sendMessage(getName() + " - You acted2 on " + object.getDef().getName());
 }

      }
      }
      }[/code]

Currently, triggerEntity() is handled by a synchronized Thread created inside the server engine itself, which is causing a number of odd side-effects, but there doesn’t appear to be any major bugs or exploits with the system so far.

The only thing the database saves is the quest’s current ‘stage’ (setStage(), getStage()) and the quest’s identifying UID and the user’s hash. This represents the player’s progression in the quest - whether they’ve just started it, they’ve already finished it or are up to the part where they collect the wool etc. All the database loading/saving is done automatically inside Quest.java when the stage value is modified or the quest is loaded.

QuestAction.class is just an enum with a list of action definitions, like MobState.class in Demonik. As you can see with triggerEntity(), any entity with an ID that has been defined as ‘associated’ with this quest will be redirected to that quest’s triggerEntity() method to be handled and controlled.

Basically, to add a new quest to the game, all that’s required is:

  • The .class file in the quests folder.
  • The client-side quest name modifications.

A brand new, unique quest will create its own database entry upon loading if necessary, so the quest creator doesn’t need to touch the database to implement new quests, nor do they have to touch the server or client’s source code (as quest names will be loaded externally client-side, and the quests assign themselves all the entity IDs they require to function in ‘define()’ so that you don’t have to touch the server code unless you’re tweaking the quest system itself).

My ideal purpose for quests is to add depth to the game instead of just ‘You require level 60 attack to wield this item’, not to create useless content to bore the players with. Most players hated RSC quests because 1) they’re lazy and 2) most of Jagex’s quests sucked. A good quest/story line makes the player actually want to complete it. Balls of wool is a bad example, but with a little imagination, you could come up with anything.

Obviously all these virtual objects could cause problems on a less-than-amazing server with 200 players all doing quests, but hey, it’s progress lolz.
